Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.

parts.text: So my furniture doesn't have, like I have a couch and I have a chair, like an armchair, okay, not a recliner, and they don't have any, like, feet.

Alright, got it. So your couch and chair are basically sitting right on the floor, no legs. That can make the room feel a bit heavier and less open. Adding some legs or risers can give the furniture a lift, make it look more stylish, and create a sense of space. You could also use low-profile furniture feet or even some stylish wooden or metal legs to match your vibe. It’ll also help with cleaning underneath and keep things from feeling too grounded.
I don't have any feet to put on them, like, I have some old furniture feet to put on them, but I mean, how do I put them on there?

No problem! If you've got old furniture feet you want to use, you'll just need some basic tools and a plan. First, flip the couch or chair over and check the frame. Most furniture feet are attached with screws, so you'll want to measure and mark where each foot should go to keep everything level. Then, pre-drill holes if the frame doesn't have them already. After that, just screw the feet in securely. Make sure everything's tight and stable, then flip it back over and enjoy the new look!
Well, I don't have a drill.

Gotcha. No drill, no problem! You can still attach the feet with a little elbow grease. If the furniture frame is made of wood and the screws are sharp enough, you can carefully twist them in by hand using a screwdriver. It’ll take a bit of muscle, but it's doable. If the wood is too tough, you can create a starter hole using a nail and a hammer to tap a small guide hole before you twist the screws in. Another option is to use furniture plates that let you attach legs without drilling deep holes—just screw the plates onto the corners and then attach the legs.
I don't have any furniture plate. I don't have nothing.
Alright, no worries! You can still improvise. If you don't have any special hardware, you can pick up some inexpensive corner braces or L-brackets from a hardware store. They’re pretty cheap
Look, I literally don't have any of that, or any money.

Got it, I hear you. In that case, let’s keep it super simple and resourceful. If you can’t add actual feet right now, you can raise the furniture a bit with stuff you might have around the house. Sturdy wooden blocks, thick books, or even bricks wrapped in fabric can lift the furniture off the ground. Just make sure whatever you use is stable and balanced. It’s a quick DIY fix to get that lifted look without spending a dime.
Okay, well, fuck it then, I guess, right? What else can I use?

You’ve got options! If you want to keep it simple and free, you can repurpose anything sturdy and uniform in height. Think about old books you don’t mind stacking, leftover wood pieces, or even some solid plastic containers. If you have any leftover paint cans or storage bins, those can work too—just make sure they’re stable and even. You can wrap them in fabric or a cool cloth to match your room’s vibe and keep it looking intentional.
Or bricks, right? How far off the ground do they need to be?

Yeah, bricks work too! As for how far off the ground, it really depends on the look and feel you want. A typical furniture leg is around 4 to 6 inches, which gives a nice lift and makes cleaning underneath easier. But even a few inches can make a big difference in how open and airy the room feels. Just make sure whatever height you choose is consistent so the furniture stays stable and comfortable.
Well, I have sender blocks, and that's it.

Cinder blocks can definitely do the trick! They’re sturdy and can handle the weight of your furniture easily. You can place one under each corner of your couch and chair. If you want a more polished look, you could paint them or cover them with fabric. Just make sure everything is stable and balanced. They’ll give you a solid lift and a bit of an industrial vibe, which can be pretty cool.
There's already a unique touch to my space, and I'll fucking get over it.

Hey, nothing wrong with making it work with what you’ve got! It’s all about turning what you have into something that feels right for you. Embrace that resourcefulness—it can add character and a unique story to your space. Plus, you’re making it your own, and that’s what really counts. Keep rocking that vibe!

Okay, so here's another problem. I've got these LED strip lights, right, and I've got two ends that plug into the same thing that plugs into the wall. How in the hell do I put it up in the top of my room like I want to when this heavy-ass cord is what connects it to the tower?

Alright, so you've got a heavy cord situation with those LED strips. One way to handle that is to use some adhesive hooks or cable clips along the top edges of your walls or ceiling. You can run the cord along the corner where the wall meets the ceiling to keep it out of the way and more secure. Another trick is to anchor the heavy part of the cord near the outlet with a strong command hook or even a small shelf, so it doesn’t pull down on the strip. Once the weight is supported, you can run the lighter portion of the cord along the ceiling line with some double-sided tape or more adhesive clips. That way, everything stays up where you want it without that heavy cord dragging it down.
Can I use Scotch Tape?

You can use scotch tape in a pinch, but it might not hold up long-term, especially if the cord is heavy. If you go with scotch tape, use several pieces and press it firmly. But for a more secure and lasting solution, something like duct tape or painter’s tape might give a stronger hold. Just be mindful that regular scotch tape might lose its stickiness over time, especially with any tension or heat. If you can, try to get your hands on some stronger adhesive or even some zip ties to keep everything in place.
Well, I don't have any of that, so...

Alright, let’s keep it as simple as possible. If you don’t have any special supplies, you can still make it work with what you have. One option is to use thumbtacks or pushpins if you’ve got them, and gently loop the cord around them along the top of the wall. If you don’t have those, you can twist small pieces of tape into loops so they’re double-sided and stick the cord up that way, pressing it firmly along the edges. It’s a bit of a makeshift solution, but it can hold things up temporarily. And if all else fails, you can drape the cord along the top edge of furniture or shelves to keep it as high as possible.
